name: cleanOfficial_General, 1. Follow standard conventions.
infoBody: I.e. the rules stated on this list and the like. E.g. CamelCasing.

name: cleanOfficial_General, 2. Keep it simple stupid
infoBody: Simpler is always better. Reduce complexity as much as possible.

name: cleanOfficial_General, 3. Boy scout rule
infoBody: Leave the campground cleaner than you found it.

name: cleanOfficial_General, 4. Always find root cause.
infoBody: Always look for the root cause of a problem.

name: cleanOfficial_Design, 1. Keep configurable data at high levels.
infoBody: Whenever you're placing a variable that may be configured, ask yourself if it could be placed at a higher level. With functionality it can typically be placed higher than with ATESTs.
exampleBad: /*Having multiple application.properties in a project. Makes it more difficult to find and also make sure you change it everywhere it needs to be changed.*/

name: cleanOfficial_Design, 2. Prefer polymorphism - to if/else or switch/case.
cleanOfficial_Design, 3. Separate multi-threading code.
infoBody:
Separate multi- from mono-thread.
Make it obvious what is what.

E.g. comment at methods what is what, when other developers can be in doubt.

name: cleanOfficial_Design, 4. Prevent over-configurability.
infoBody:
Single responsibility:
Rather have several seperate classes and methods which does similar things. Than having few with many parameters, even though it ensures a high degree of configurability.

name: cleanOfficial_Design, 5. Use dependency injection.
cleanOfficial_Design, 6. Follow Law of Demeter.
infoBody: A class should know only its direct dependencies.

name: cleanOfficial_Understandability, 1. Be consistent.
infoBody: If you do something a certain way, do all similar things in the same way.

name: cleanOfficial_Understandability, 2. Use explanatory variables.
cleanOfficial_Understandability, 3. Encapsulate boundary conditions.
infoBody: Boundary conditions are hard to keep track of. Put the processing for them in one place.

name: cleanOfficial_Understandability, 4. Prefer dedicated value objects to primitive type.
cleanOfficial_Understandability, 5. Avoid logical dependency.
infoBody: Don't write methods which works correctly depending on something else in the same class.

name: cleanOfficial_Understandability, 6. Avoid negative conditionals.
references: Robert's Rules of Coders: #8 Avoid Negative Conditionals And Method Names

name: cleanOfficial_Names, 1. Choose descriptive and unambiguous names.
cleanOfficial_Names, 2. Make meaningful distinction.
infoBody: And obvious. Make it easy to spot the difference between different variables, methods etc.

name: cleanOfficial_Names, 3. Use pronounceable names.
cleanOfficial_Names, 4. Use searchable names.
cleanOfficial_Names, 5. Replace magic numbers with named constants.
references: Replace Magic Number with Symbolic Constant

name: cleanOfficial_Names, 6. Avoid encodings. Don't append prefixes or type information.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 1. Small.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 2. Do one thing.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 3. Use descriptive names.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 4. Prefer fewer arguments.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 5. Have no side effects.
cleanOfficial_Functions, 6. Don't use flag arguments.
infoBody: Split method into several independent methods that can be called from the client without the flag.

name: cleanOfficial_Comments, 1. Always try to explain yourself in code.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 2. Don't be redundant.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 3. Don't add obvious noise.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 4. Don't use closing brace comments.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 5. Don't comment out code. Just remove.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 6. Use as explanation of intent.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 7. Use as clarification of code.
cleanOfficial_Comments, 8. Use as warning of consequences.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 1. Separate concepts vertically.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 2. Related code should appear vertically dense.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 3. Declare variables close to their usage.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 4. Dependent functions should be close.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 5. Similar functions should be close.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 6. Place functions in the downward direction.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 7. Keep lines short.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 8. Don't use horizontal alignment.
cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 9. Use white space to associate related things.
infoBody: Use white space to associate related things and disassociate weakly related.

name: cleanOfficial_Source code structure, 10. Don't break indentation.
infoBody: I.e. don't mess with automated indentation of the IDE. And make sure your IDE is setup as agreed upon for the project. It's 4 spaces.

name: cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 1. Hide internal structure.
infoBody: Minimize the amount of methods and variables which are public. So you need to know as little as possible about the classes you use.

name: cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 2. Prefer data structures.
infoBody: Use data structure rather than many methods.

name: cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 3. Avoid hybrids structures
infoBody: (half object and half data).

name: cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 4. Should be small.
cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 5. Do one thing.
cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 6. Small number of instance variables.
cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 7. Base class should know nothing about their derivatives.
cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 8. Better to have many functions than...
infoBody: ...to pass some code into a function to select a behavior.

name: cleanOfficial_Objects and data structures, 9. Prefer non-static methods to static methods.
cleanOfficial_Tests, 1. One assert per test.
infoBody: This rules is targeted unit testing and not the ATEST flows which often need more than one assertion per test.

name: cleanOfficial_Tests, 2. Readable.
cleanOfficial_Tests, 3. Fast.
cleanOfficial_Tests, 4. Independent.
cleanOfficial_Tests, 5. Repeatable.
infoBody: Watch out for live index, using physical days date,  random methods and sequens indexing across multiple test runs.

name: cleanOfficial_Code smells, 1. Rigidity. The software is difficult to change.
infoBody: A small change causes a cascade of subsequent changes.

name: cleanOfficial_Code smells, 2. Fragility.
infoBody: The software breaks in many places due to a single change.

name: cleanOfficial_Code smells, 3. Immobility.
infoBody: You cannot reuse parts of the code in other projects because of involved risks and high effort.

name: cleanOfficial_Code smells, 4. Needless Complexity.
cleanOfficial_Code smells, 5. Needless Repetition.
cleanOfficial_Code smells, 6. Opacity. The code is hard to understand.
reviewOfficia_Preconditions, 1. Developers should have built and tested the code locally...
infoBody: ...before handing it over to a reviewer

name: reviewOfficia_Preconditions, 2. The code should be self-explainable...
infoBody: ...if not comments are required.

name: reviewOfficia_Preconditions, 3. Tasks shall never be too big for the review...
infoBody: ...to be able to be done in less than two hours. If a developer gets a task that by mistake is too big, then divide it into smaller cohesive tasks.

name: reviewOfficia_Preconditions, 4. Kunne nogle af PSRM scriptsne flyttes over i Java?
reviewOfficia_Preconditions, 5. Kunne noget af den logik der ligger på databasen flyttes over i Java?
reviewOfficia_Instructions, 1. Never review for longer than two hours or...
infoBody: more than about 400 lines of code.

name: reviewOfficia_Instructions, 2.  Check if the code follows our coding conventions
infoBody: i.e. Clean Code.

name: reviewOfficia_Instructions, 3. Do you understand what the code does?
infoBody: Do you understand the comments?

name: reviewOfficia_Instructions, 4. Does it work, that is not only work but work as...
infoBody:
...the requirements instruct. Make sure data is both received and passed on correctly the handshake is the key.
I.e. don't just verify that the value you got in your test is correct but make sure that the data object always delivers what is expected. E.g. if a field has no input, should it return null or nut include that field?

name: reviewOfficia_Instructions, 5. Check for errors, vulnerabilities, inconsistency and redundant code.
reviewOfficia_Instructions, 6. Give constructive pointers in a positive attitude.
reviewOfficia_Instructions, 7. Remember that reviewing code is an excellent way to learn...
infoBody: ... from your fellow developers.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 1. There should be 0 project warnings in IntelliJ...
infoBody:
...and SonarQube (SonarLint if you don't have full)
As a minimum, do not introduce new warnings with code you have written. Ideally, remove some of the warnings in the files you're working on.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 2. There should always be checked for null to avoid the...
infoBody: ...Null Pointer Exceptions at runtime.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 3. Check for proper logging of ALL business decisions...
infoBody:
...And their foundation.
So every action a case worker can make which influences (or has consequences for) a citizien / case should always be logged.
There is a correct way and place to log these. So don't make up your own but ask a colleague if you're in doubt about how and where.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 4. Does the names on the classes and methods reflect what they do?
reviewOfficia_Checklist, 5. Check database queries if they are optimized. Or if using...
infoBody:
...hibernate query language check that the code result in optimized SQL arriving on the database.
Take it from “working” to a more performant and efficient solution before submitting your solution.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 6. Are there multiple API requests/Service calls,...
infoBody: ...could they be optimized are they to wide?

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 7. Does it load/get data for things that are not used?
reviewOfficia_Checklist, 8. Can caching improve performance?
infoBody:
Ask yourself, do you need to load all that data each time the code is run? Is there something I can cache to improve performance?
Also, perhaps at the beginning at a session and not everytime you use the values…
E.g. in batchjobs, maybe don't load the same data multiple times.

name: reviewOfficia_Checklist, 9. For security, send/receive only the absolutely needed information.
reviewOfficia_Checklist, 10. Does the methods do only one thing or...
infoBody: ...very little think IntelliJ extract.

name: othCleanSolid_Disinformation
infoBody:
Avoid disinformation.
e.g. dont call it claimList if it's not a list but a HashMap.
exampleBad: HashMap<Date, Money> claimList = new HashMap<Date, Money>();

name: othCleanSolid_Pronounceable naming
infoBody: Use pronounceable names, so you can more easily have a verbal discussion with colleagues about them. Even for those with a strict character limit.

name: othCleanSolid_Flag arguments, do not use.
infoBody: Don't use flag arguments. Meaning don't pass a boolean as an argument into a function. As in, if true do this, if false do that. Then create two functions instead.
exampleGood:
Claim GetFirstMainClaimInList(ClaimList claims) {...}
Claim GetFirstRelatedClaimInList(ClaimList claims) {...}

name: othCleanSolid_Arguments, maximum three
infoBody: If you need more than three, consider if some of them could 'be grouped' in an object first.
exampleBad: RepossessionCase CreateRepossessionCase(Calendar dateRepoStart, String claimId, Money debtAmount, Calendar receiveDate, Money originalDebtAmount) {...}

name: othCleanSolid_Arguments, order them as one would expect
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook
exampleBad: Claim CreateClaim(Money currentAmount, Date receiveDate, Money originalAmount) {...}
exampleGood: Claim CreateClaim(Date receiveDate, Money originalAmount, Money currentAmount) {...}

name: othCleanSolid_Variables, declaration placement.
infoBody: Declare variables close to their usage. Unless they are used throughout the class, then declare them at the top.
references: Clean Code, p. 192 'Variable Declarations' and p. 193 'Instance variables'

name: othCleanSolid_Keep lines within 120 characters
infoBody: It's indicated by a vertical grey line in IntelliJ.

name: othCleanSolid_Variables, (almost) never use public
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook

name: othCleanSolid_Train-wrecks, e.g. 'getSomething().getOtherThing().getGetTheLastThing();'
infoBody: Note: Clean Code recommends the opposite of what we do in 'Inddrivelsesprogrammet.'

name: othCleanSolid_Outlier cases, create a function
infoBody: A minor with debt to be collected is an outlier case. [NOTE: this is still a suggestion, it has not yet been decided what to do about those special case scenarios]
exampleGood:
Claim CreateRepossessionCase(ClaimList claims) {...}
Claim CreateRepossessionCaseForMinor(ClaimList claims) {IncludeGuardian(...); }
references: Clean Code, p. 237 'Define the Normal Flow'

name: othCleanSolid_Imports, don't use wildcards
infoBody: Note: Clean Code recommends the opposite of what we do in 'Inddrivelsesprogrammet.' This rule follows our own recommendations.
references: Clean Code, p. 543 'Avoid Long Import Lists by Using Wildcards'

name: othCleanSolid_Single responsibility, FUNCTION
infoBody:
This is the same noted as '10. Does the methods do only one thing or very little think IntelliJ extract.' in Code_review.xlsx

If your function name has the word 'and' in it, it probably does more than one thing and should be split up.
If you can use IntelliJ extract on it, it probably should be divided into more than one function.
Lastly, you should not need to indent more than twice within a function.
references: SOLID Design Principles Explained: The Single Responsibility Principle

name: othCleanSolid_Single responsibility, CLASS
infoBody:
You should be able to give your class a concise name.
It should only have one reason to change.
exampleGood:
public class CourtFeeStopTest {...}
public class CourtFeeRecalculationTest {...}
references: SOLID Design Principles Explained: The Single Responsibility Principle

name: othCleanSolid_Comments should be kept at a minimum, use explanatory code instead.
infoBody: Why: comments are at a greater risk of becoming outdated than actual code. Thus, using explanatory code mitigates the risk of misinformation.
exampleBad: Date date = new Date(2019, 6, 30); //Creating the last date in June 2019

name: othCleanSolid_Catch block, don't use your own with jUnit
infoBody: Do not write your own catch block. Method of jUnit are able to catch them. If you use your own catch block you are doing redundant code.

name: othCleanSolid_Namelengths, should correspond to scope
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook
references: Clean Code, p. 94 'Use Searchable Names', 4th paragraph

name: othCleanSolid_Prefix, use it in variable names when context isn't obvious
infoBody:
Ideally context is obvious from the variables being grouped in small single purpose classes.

Alternatively, use a prefix to state the context.
exampleBad:
String id, address, name;
String id2, address2, size2;
exampleGood:
String employeeId, employeeAddress, employeeName;
string roomId, roomAddress, roomSize;

name: othCleanSolid_Switch statements, should be avoided
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook

name: othCleanSolid_null, use exceptions instead of returning or passing null
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook

name: othCleanSolid_ATEST structure: BUILD-OPERATE-CHECK
infoBody: _MoreInfoInBook

name: othCleanSolid_Functions used in more than one test, place them in utility classes
infoBody: Use utility classes for when writing tests. It's also normal and good practice to let those evolve over time.

name: othCleanSolid_Assertions, keep them to a minimum
infoBody:
Keep the amount of asserts in a test to a minimum. If you have many, consider splitting up the test into more tests.

And test only one "concept" per test.
The rule is more vaguely defined here than in the book because the test data setup in 'Inddrivelsesprogrammet' is rather cumbersome and we save execution time by grouping tests.

name: othCleanSolid_Proper naming of variables, functions and classes
infoBody:
The name should answer:
- Why it exists
- What it does
- How it is used

name: othCleanSolid_Open-closed. Follow open-closed principle
infoBody:
Since we use Clean Code, we should use Polymorphic version.
Meaning: "Interface specifications can be reused through inheritance but implementation need not be. The existing interface is closed to modifications and new implementations must, at a minimum, implement that interface."
references: The Open/Closed Principle with Code Examples

name: othCleanSolid_Liskov Substitution Principle
infoBody:
"S is a subtype of T, then objects of type T may be replaced with objects of type S" 
It's a complex principle and it's recommended to look more into the references.
It has not yet been clarified whether we in reality follow this principle in 'Inddrivelsesprogrammet'.
references: The Liskov Substitution Principle with Code Examples

name: othCleanSolid_Interface segregation principle
infoBody: '...the interface segregation principle (ISP) states that no code should be forced to depend on methods it does not use. ISP splits interfaces that are very large into smaller and more specific ones so that clients will only have to know about the methods that are of interest to them' - Wiki

name: othCleanSolid_Dependency inversion principle
infoBody:
'The principle states:[1]

High-level modules should not import anything from low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions (e.g., interfaces).
Abstractions should not depend on details. Details (concrete implementations) should depend on abstractions.' - Wiki
references: Dependency Inversion Principle with Code Examples
